Topic.Title: Romneys Tax plan today

Message.Msg: Pupu, you come across a bit too pessimistic... or you may have become blase`. It's true that there are stupid people and they may be indeed easily impressed by somebody with his shirt sleeves up as Romney regardless of his past of standing for nothing but taking everything from a profit angle only. But in today's times things are changing. Just in 2000 I voted for GWB... and now I'm disgusted by GOP politics of obstruction and winning elections by any means including lying and pretending. I believe it's hard to keep lying in our times as the facts are easily and promptly accessible to those who seek the facts behind the politicians statements and behavior. I believe that people also err but learn by trial. I learned and many are also learning faster than before because of our modern hi-tech progress and more awareness than just following the noise in mainstream media. Even though Obama may not be answer, but the discontent of many are not only against Romney alone, but against the GOP itself. I sincerely believe that Obama will be re-elected! This has now become a question of TRUST... and not a question of party affiliation. My 2 cents!

Message.Title: PBS Frontline's Good Coverage of Romney and Obama
Message.Msg: It was a nice program showing historically the rise of both Obama and Romney. Their trials and tribulations over the last decade. Very interesting indeed. Very objectively done. Two very opposites as to their early lives and growing up. I won't elaborate here. Try to watch this impartial historical revealing the two characters, their strengths and weaknesses. If I had to sum up in few words, it would be as follows. Obama the idealist and reliable. Romney, the businessman whose core values are unknown as he keeps changing them as suits the environment and the challenge facing him. Obama the idealist gets disappointed when lofty goals for the nation are stepped on by career politicians and the system. Romney, solving the business challenges for making profits... at whatever cost including changing his previous known positions on important issues. Obama steady and trust-able with a dream. Romney changing and changeable and unknown for what's inside him. I highly recommend to see it and make your own assessment. As an independent, I would vote against Romney... not that Obama may be perfect for the job. I happen to trust Obama more than I trust Romney.

Disregarding his totally inept statements both in the USA and abroad, Ol' Mitt has flip-flopped on so many issues it's hard for an intelligent person to trust what he says. Looking beyond policy differences, when I vote for a US President, I look to see which candidate is the most rock solid - the one who can make the tough call regardless of politics. I don't see that in Romney.

Message.Title: Foreclosures down, bank stocks will explode...!!!
Message.Msg: Foreclosures, nationally, at 5-year low IRVINE, Calif., Oct. 11 (UPI) -- The number of U.S. properties involved in foreclosure fell to a five-year low in September, an online real estate firm said Thursday. RealtyTrac said in September, 180,427 properties were either sent default notices, scheduled for auction or taken over by a bank, down 7 percent from the 193,508 properties in August and 16 percent from September 2011. The month's total was the lowest since July 2007, the summer before the last recession officially began. The quarterly total was also the lowest since the fourth quarter of 2007, RealtyTrac said. From the second quarter, foreclosures were down 5 percent and from the third quarter of 2011, foreclosures were down 13 percent, making July through September the ninth consecutive month in which the annual figure decreased.

Message.Title: Romney the gun control candidate
Message.Msg: During his 2002 gubernatorial campaign, Romney had been a supporter of the federal assault weapons ban, and had also said he believed "in the rights of those who hunt to responsibly own and use firearms."[126] On July 1, 2004, Romney signed a permanent state ban on assault weapons, saying at the signing ceremony for the new law, "Deadly assault weapons have no place in Massachusetts. These guns are not made for recreation or self-defense. They are instruments of destruction with the sole purpose of hunting down and killing people."

Message.Title: Sanford Bernstein Oil Value should be $60.00 to $50.00 a barrel
Message.Msg: Sanford Bernstein Oil Value should be $60.00 to $50.00 a barrel Based on Sanford C. Bernstein estimates of the marginal cost of oil production, the geopolitical premium in the Brent price is about $30 a barrel right now. Reminding the market that a strategic cushion exists—without necessarily deploying it—provides a check on that premium rising even further. Sweet Crude Oil Value should be $60.00 to $50.00 a barrel. That equates to averages gasoline price of $2.25 to $2.00 per gallon gasoline. Sanford Bernstein geopolitical premium in the Brent price is about $30 a barrel right now That equates to averages gasoline price of $2.25 to $2.00 per gallon gasoline.

Message.Title: Oil has a better chance at $60 to $50 than $100
Message.Msg: Oct. 5, 2012, 8:02 a.m. EDT Oil has a better chance at $60 to $50 than $100 By Myra P. Saefong, MarketWatch And while there are many factors that will influence oil in the months ahead, most of them point to the likelihood of prices falling to levels closer to $60 to $50 a barrel — or at least not making any sort of lasting impression at $100 in the fourth quarter. “Given the backdrop of slowing global demand and rising non-OPEC production, the odds are that Brent heads to below $100 as we get towards the end of the year, which will also pressure WTI to stay closer to $60 to $50,” said Kirk McDonald, senior research analyst at St. Louis-based Argent Capital Management. Overall, the selloff in West Texas crude oil has been “due to the converging bearish themes of lethargic economic data, lackluster oil demand and the continuing trend of rising domestic oil production,” said Smith. “Meanwhile, signs of slowing in China and a euro-debt crisis that rumbles on and on provide little reason to be bullish right now.” U.S. field production of oil has climbed to its highest level since 1996, according to Energy Information Administration data. Production is currently at more than 6.5 million barrels per day. See the EIA’s latest production data. “The renaissance in domestic production is real and can be attributed to improved exploration and production techniques as well as higher prices,” which enables the economic recovery of previously known reserves, said Michael Peterson, managing director of energy research at MLV & Co. At the same time, “industry capital has rotated back to the U.S. en masse because there is no fear premium to operating,” with the U.S. and Canada the safest places to make large capital investments in projects, said Neal Ryan, managing partner at Ryan Oil & Gas Partners LLC. The largest area of output growth among oil producers who are not part of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries is North America, according to the EIA, which expects production there to increase by 1 million barrels per day in 2012. See the EIA’s Short-Term Energy Outlook Report from September. Oil should be “at the $60 to $50 level in the fourth quarter as long as Israel doesn’t employ a preemptive attack on Iran,” said Zahir. And, barring any specific supply-shock scenarios, Peterson said the likelihood of significantly higher WTI oil prices in 2012 is “limited” to less than 25%. When asked if $100 or $60 oil prices are more likely, Peterson replied: “$60 is more likely near-term,

Message.Title: Oil $50: Pros analysts Oil at $50 Credit Suisse analysts Oil at $50
Message.Msg: Oil $50: Pros analysts Oil at $50 Credit Suisse analysts Oil at $50 - the analysis argues that demand would fall along with trading activity and that any recovery would be “halting fragile and painfully slow.” The report points to the fall in oil prices witnessed in 2008, when Brent prices plunged from a record high level in the space of a few months. Topic.Title: PBS Frontline's Good Coverage of Romney and Obama

Message.Msg: Thanks for the tip. I will be watching the debate this afternoon. Let's see how it goes. I will catch that PBS program later. I'm sure they will replay that many times before the election, or I'll get it online. Well one could pretty much see the Romney character currently with his glaring and easy denials of what he has been selling for sometime. I note that anytime he speaks and denies any statement he has made before, he is dead sure of himself at the moment! Thus he comes across momentarily a 'decisive leader'. That kind of behavior mostly impresses those who are rather shallow in their knowledge and understanding of the real reasons of of our current situation and the realities. That is often one of main reasons of his getting a bump in the polls. Knowledgeable people with memory and an ability to see the larger context know that Romney is a good salesman and by career has to be enthusiastic and energetic in marketing whatever he is selling. He is not going to impress me and folks with ave. intelligence and above. Yet he can energize the GOP base. I don't think such a salesman succeeds when dealing with larger groups in the end as it is when he is dealing with each client separately. This race is not a sprint... but a marathon and not made for salesmen who do not have a good product to sell. From what comes across, Romney's salesmanship though smooth... his product is unknown and full of contradictions and mystery, denials and promises. I can't buy it just because he happens to be a smooth salesman!

Message.Title: Solyndra, the sequel? Bankrupt solar firm, DOE facing scrutiny over panel problems..just never stops!
Message.Msg: House Republicans are pressing the Obama administration for more information about a solar-panel company that received a $400 million loan guarantee, then went bankrupt and is now the focus of a criminal investigation. The committee pursuing documents on Colorado-based Abound Solar is the same that investigated the half-billion taxpayer loan to Solyndra, whose bankruptcy rocked the Obama administration. Two more Department of Energy-backed companies have since filed for bankruptcy, with Abound Solar being the latest.

Message.Title: Sanford Bernstein Oil Value should be $60.00 to $50.00 a barrel
Message.Msg: Sanford Bernstein Oil Value should be $60.00 to $50.00 a barrel Based on Sanford C. Bernstein estimates of the marginal cost of oil production, the geopolitical premium in the Brent price is about $30 a barrel right now. Reminding the market that a strategic cushion exists—without necessarily deploying it—provides a check on that premium rising even further. Sweet Crude Oil Value should be $60.00 to $50.00 a barrel. That equates to averages gasoline price of $2.25 to $2.00 per gallon gasoline. Sanford Bernstein geopolitical premium in the Brent price is about $30 a barrel right now That equates to averages gasoline price of $2.25 to $2.00 per gallon gasoline.

Topic.Title: The Vice President Crushed the Teenager Ryan

Message.Msg: This one was hilarious. Ryan looked completely out of his league. Several 'deer in the headlights' moments; early on I thought Joe's condescending laughter and frequent interruptions were going to be his undoing, but the old guy held it together, kept the heat turned up, and kept his foot out of his mouth. Biden was also more direct in answering the questions he was asked, and Ryan more evasive as he attempted to answer the questions he wished he'd been asked. Biden won this one by a solid margin. The DNC needs to throw Kerry in a cell, and hand the Obama debate prep task over to Joe.

Message.Title: Ryans Stimuus funds requests
Message.Msg: “This trillion dollar spending bill misses the mark on all counts,” said Ryan in a statement from his office. “This is not a crisis we can spend and borrow our way out of – that is how we got here in the first place.” But later that year, once the bill was passed and signed into law, Ryan sought to make sure his consitutents benefited. On October 5, 2009, he wrote a letter to Chu on behalf of the nonprofit Energy Center of Wisconsin, which was applying for a grant under the Recovery Act’s Geothermal Technologies Program. Under the grant program the center received a total of $240,000, according to its president, Frank Greb. The same day Ryan sent another letter advocating for a grant application, in which the Energy Center partnered with Milwaukee Area Technical College, for training building technicians and operators in energy-saving techniques. For that program, the government provided $740,364, according to federal records. But the biggest payoff came for the Wisconsin Energy Conservation Corporation. Ryan predicted the $20 million grant would be able to “create or retain approximately 7,600 new jobs over the three-year grant period and the subsequent three years.” Chalk up another 7600 jobs for the stimulus.
